<s>all colours disappear. 
The whole of this new Hypothesis may be comprized in 
two Articles. 
1st. All prismatic phenomena which appear between plane 
glass plates or lenses, are caused by the interference of the refracting 
strata of their contiguous surfaces. 
2d. In all cases the intensity of colour is (<u>caeteris paribus<\u>) pro-
portional to the difference between the refractive powers of said 
plates or lenses & those of the circumambient media. 
If the above theory is well founded; it is also probable that 
primary phenomena, as well as the colours of thin plates are 
caused by the interference of the refracting strata of <u>internal<\u> surfaces 
& those of Binaries by the interference  of the strata of <u>external<\u> 
surfaces; & altho this opinion may seem to disagree with 
the illustration given by <s>plate<\s> fig 18. (which to avoid 
confusion was adapted to the simplest case) the difficulty is 
removed by supposing the dotted rings to represent Binaries 
instead of primaries, & that the latter do not commence untill 
after the surfaces have approached much within the limits 
sufficient for producing the former, conformable to the 33d 
experiment; which may be still farther corroborated by the 
following. 
Ex. 37. A fragment of one of the glass globes before mentioned, 
altho too thick to show colours in itself, was interposed between 
two plane glass plates; it did not present the appearance 
of Binaries; altho at the same time primary fringes appeared 
on both sides of the fragment where it was in contact with the 
contiguous surfaces of the glass plates. in this case there was 
an interval between the plates of more than three times that which was sufficient 
to produce primaries, & yet not great enough to present the 
appearance of Binaries. 
This opinion is corroborated by the following facts. 1st nothing 
similar to Binary spectra have yet been  perceived either 
in soap bubbles, or thin glass plates. 2d. there is a close similarity 
between the colours of primary+ phenomena, & those of thin 
plates 
+ The 2d species of primaries which were discovered in the 23d experi-
ment must be taken as an exception to this rule; & had it not been 
to avoid the necessity of inventing a new term to express them 
by, perhaps they should have been considered as belonging to a 3d 
genera, different from both the other two. <\s>
